What do you mean by control mode? Did you mean autonomous mode? If so, read this: Choosing an Autonomous Program — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

It’s cleanest to deploy a different binary for each control scheme since they don’t get switched often. With that said, you can use DriverStation (WPILib API 2021.3.1) to determine whether there’s an Xbox controller or joystick plugged in.

You have to be able to read API documentation comfortably before you can make good use of a large library like WPILib. Spend some time looking at the documentation and see if you can grasp how it relates to the code in usage.

Okay two immediate questions:
What do you mean by “set input single Xbox controller”?
Is this something to do when you’re setting up button mappings to actions at the start of your program?

And 2:
If I plug in a joystick and an Xbox, what should happen?

sorry accidentally sent heres the full message

so all i want to do is

 If xbox controller and operator controller plugged in set input Dual controller
 else if Joystick and operator controller plugged in set input Joystick Control
 else if Xbox Controller plugged in set input Single Xbox Controller
 else set input Single Xbox Controller

Oblarg:

Spend some time looking at the documentation and see if you can grasp how it relates to the code in usage.

To assist with this, here’s a slide deck I present to our students every year. It’s a bit outdated, but the core concepts should answer some of the questions about “how to apply javadocs to writing java”.

Java for Robots.pdf (1.4 MB)

Konnor:

but theres nothing i see about changing which is the input value

Fair enough. I suspect this will be custom to your codebase.

Here’s one way to split the problem up:

  1. Determine if the robot should be running in “single controller” or “double controller” mode
  2. Based on (1), calculate “operator commands” from the correct controller
  3. Pass those operator commands to downstream pieces of software that need the information.

Core to this concept: I define the idea of “operator commands” to differentiate the intent of the driver(s) from the actual buttons and axes they use. For example: “Fwd/Rev Speed Command” could be an operator command. The drivetrain always needs to know the Fwd/Rev Speed command. However, depending on single/double controller mode, it might have to come from different joysticks.

Philosophical aside to keep in mind: “Code” is just a tool - it’s like pencil and paper.

When writing an essay, you don’t grab your pencil and paper and start writing words immediately. Rather, you first think and plan about what you want your essay to say. You form a thesis. You gather supporting information. You outline and plan the flow. Then, and only then, pencil hits paper, and the first draft starts.

Similarly, when writing software: You always start by defining what you want your robot to do. Then, after sufficient planning and breakdown of the problem, you express a desired behavior through code.
